climbs.name: Wiretap
climbs.fa: Mark Leonard an David Baltz around the same time as

content.description: Technical climbing gets you past a not so good looking pin to a button-head bolt. Pro comes from thin cams in horizontals. I found the crux to be right after the bolt. The following bulge is easier that it looks. After this you follow a flaring grove towards the roof and step right just before you reach it.   I found this part very heady. The guidebook calls the pro tricky, but it's not just hard to spot, but also just not that good IMO. While this part is easier than the start there are some 10- moves above not-as-good-as-you-want-it pro.
content.protection: 2 sets of cams to #.75 c4, singles up to #3 c4. One #5.
content.location: left of Cloak and Dagger. Starts on top of the rock pile under the pin in the horizontal.

climbs.name: Thunderstruck
climbs.fa: Lee Brinckerhoff, Bryan Pletta and Eric Whitbeck

content.description:
Follow the right leaning arete to a hard crux right where the arete straightens out, then an intimidating rock over back to your left to gain a good horizontal break and the end of the real difficulties. 

  The first bit moving up and right along the arete is probably 5.11'ish and ends at a nice two handed mail slot. Get a good shake because it is on for the next 15 feet or so, powerful to start then quite technical ending at a horizontal. Follow an easier crack from the horizontal up to the anchors.
content.location: The obvious steep right leaning arete on the right end of the main section of wall.

content.description: Climb the crack though a series of roofs, to an intimidating final largest and widest of roofs. The difficulty seems to come more from the consistancy rather than a stopper move.
content.protection: Double set of cams to a #3 camalot and one larger, nuts, runners for the roofs.
content.location: -Starts from the beginning of the ledge that Autum Ivy starts off of.   - Top out and rap back down or walk around.

content.description: Start just about at the same spot as Dossier, but step L into the L arching corner after the initial moves getting off the ground.  There are a few cruxes, first is clearing the roofs and L trending overlaps at the end of the initial corner system.   This section is all good holds and liebacks with steepish.  The second crux is more techy with thin gear and less secure climbing.  The final section is a nice easier ramble to the anchors.
content.protection: Rack up to a number 2 camalot, bring a selection of thin nuts for the upper thin section.  The pro is there just small. There is a 2 bolt chain anchor at the top.
content.location: This route would be the 3rd in from the left end.  Same start as Dossier but diverges basically right off the ground.  It sits just right of a tall tree growing only a couple feet from the wall.

content.description: The route is quality sustained 5.8ish climbing with classic Sandia climbing and protection.  Meaning somewhat tricky pro for the grade and technical face climbing.  It seems that there are a couple of cruxes one about half height and the other closer to the top.  Fun and moderate climbing on the Clandestine Wall.
content.protection: The route has two bolts and a solid two bolt anchor with chains. A light rack with small cams up to a 1 or 2 inch piece.  Typical Sandias pro; little seams, horizontals, and discontinuous cracks.
content.location: The route is on the far left side of the crag.  It sits right next to Boogers and Chocolate.  Start in a corner crack system in clean rock 10-12 ft right of Boogers and Chocolate.  Rappel or lower from chain anchor.

climbs.name: Event Horizon
climbs.fa: FFA, Nathan Bancroft, bolted by Marc Beverly and Lee Brinckerhoff

content.description:
The line of strength up the intimidating, steep red wall.

 The wall is broken by prominent horizontals that provide great rests between very difficult boulder problems. The first involves some very small holds that you have to bear down on for a long reach. The second has sloping side pulls and the third is kind of barn doorish. A final intimidating, i.e. runout, but easier section leads to the anchor.

 It is possible to avoid the last bit and probably at the same grade by stepping right to the anchor of Thunderstruck, though the original route heads up higher and left.
content.location: Beautiful red wall right of Cat Daddy

content.description: Climb the right angling ramp (awkward) which steepens into a beautiful but short corner for the crux. Continue up and right and merge with Wiretap just in time for its flared, slightly runout grooves. Finish at the same big tree.
content.protection: Cams up to #2 Camalot with some doubles in small-medium sizes, stoppers with some doubles in medium sizes. The upper section (Wiretap) might take a big cam but probably not worth it.
content.location: Starts with the shallow left facing corner about 25 feet left of Wiretap.

climbs.name: Cloak and Dagger
climbs.fa: William Penner and Mick Schein, September 2007

content.description: Cloak and Dagger is located on the left center portion of the Clandestine Wall right of the obvious large boulder at the base of the cliff that marks the start of Wiretap. Climb up past 2 pins and some bolts to a thin finger crack on the upper headwall. Excellent face climbing and a devious upper section. Tops out at the rappel tree.

This was for a long time the hardest completed route in the Sandias and unrepeated on lead. Climbs the obvious crack splitting the steep red wall. The majority of the route is probably hard 5.11+ to a difficult and technical boulder problem at the top. 

  Climb the varied and steep crack till it pinches off as it curves to the right, do crux moves onto the slab and step right to the bolted anchor of Event Horizon or step back left and climb crumbly rock with a fair bit of lichen to the Autum Ivy anchors. 

  Rarely lead, possible to TR from the Autum Ivy anchors with a 70m rope.
content.protection: RP's, double set of cams to #2 camalot, with more in the off fingers size, bolt anchor.
content.location: Obvious steep crack just right of the ledge spitting the slightly overhanging red wall.

content.description: Nice moderate route on the Clandestine Wall. The rock is very good the pro is all there but is hidden from below so the route is a bit committing for the grade (typical and classic Sandias climbing).  The crux is about 20ft up in the form of stemming and a corner change but the upper corner is only slightly easier.
content.protection: A light rack up to a #1 Camalot, bring small cams and nuts.  No bolts on the pitch but there is a bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: The route is currently the furthest left hand route on the wall. The climb starts just right of a large boulder before the base area becomes 3rd class terrain.  There is a clean red corner about 15-20 ft off the ground.  The climb ends at a nice ledge and new bolted anchors 100ft up.

content.description: Starts off the right end of the ledge with difficult to protect climbing but relatively easy for the route, continue up the crack till it pinches off and clip the bolt, do the first crux to where the crack opens back up. Continue up the crack past a thin section, second crux, to a ledge on the right and anchors
content.protection: At least a double set of cams to a #1 camalot, possibly more in the fingers and thin fingers sizes, stoppers and one bolt
content.location: -Starts off the right end of the ledge in the middle of the wall.   -Lower back to the ground or TR with a 70m rope

content.description: The best difficult crag in the Sandias. Skinwalker may be the best 5.10 pitch in the entire range and Autumn Ivy and Cat Daddy are must-dos for the Sandia hardman.
